an3.11:1.1: “Mendicants, a well-known mendicant who has three qualities is acting for the hurt and unhappiness of the people, for the harm, hurt, and suffering of gods and humans.
an3.11:1.3: They encourage deeds of body and speech, as well as principles, that don’t reinforce good qualities.
an3.11:1.4: A well-known mendicant who has these three qualities is acting for the hurt and unhappiness of the people, for the harm, hurt, and suffering of gods and humans.
an3.11:2.1: A well-known mendicant who has three qualities is acting for the welfare and happiness of the people, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.
an3.11:2.3: They encourage deeds of body and speech, as well as principles, that reinforce good qualities.
an3.11:2.4: A well-known mendicant who has these three qualities is acting for the welfare and happiness of the people, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.”
